Mattias Fagerlund wrote:

>simulations than frequent trading. And it's a big problem, because on a
>long time series (10 years), it's easy to pick 10 good buy spots and 10
>good sell spots and earn fantastic profits, but it's harder to pick 100
>such spots. 
>
>And if you evolve something that trades well once in 10 years, that's less
>likely to perform well out of bounds than something that trades well 1000
>times in 10 years.
>  
>
Consider that there may be certain rare events that have a very 
distinctive signature leading up to them - and that you can make money 
on if you spot the signature. A possible example would be the collapse 
of sterling in 1992, which many currency traders profited from, even the 
relative late comers I guess.

But do you want to wait around for (possibly) years to make relatively 
few big 'bets' (high risk, eggs in one basket scenario), or do you want 
a system that makes more frequent smaller bets? (Trading being a form of 
betting). Now it would be nice to have a system quietly looking out for 
those big bet scenario's 24/7 just to highlight them so you can make an 
informed judgement whether to act, but I see this as being a completely 
seperate system to one that looks for short term trades. Many smaller 
trades seems intuitively safer, if the system makes a loss, it does so 
gradually and you can very calmly choose to stop trading, re-evaluate 
your position, rethink the prediction model, etc.

>Currently, I severely punish infrequent trading because I view it as a
>form of overfitting.
>  
>
I definitely see overfitting as being a problem because the only way to 
reduce it is to test against larger test data sets (thus slowing 
evaluation), even then one big gain on one data set could skew a fitness 
score. I had considered that a network with a confidence output that it 
keeps low most of the time, and which only goes high when it's very sure 
of making profit would be a good network. A sort of "if you aint got 
anything interesting to say, don't say anything at all" approach to 
prediction :)  But I can definitely see how overfitting might put the 
dampers on this idea, beside which it goes against my comments in the 
previous paragraph - few trades = bad.


> I find that infrequent trading is more of a problem in my current
>
>>This is a valuable (and profitable) system in a trending market,
>>although it typically boils down to "it's going up - buy, then sell
>>when it stops going up". It tends to be awful in a sideways market.
>>    
>>
A network should be able to detect these different market states and 
decide that it performs poorly in those conditions and thus decide to 
bail out of trading (low confidence). So low frequency of trades might 
not be pad per se *if* there were particular conditions where a network 
were 'in it's element' and starts to give trading commands at high 
frequency for a while, going quiet later when market conditions change.

A complete trading system might be made up of many of these specialist 
networks, each kicking in under different circumstances.

Whatever approaches folks try, I personally absolutely stand by the 
concept of some form of confidence factor. Another idea that crops up is 
to try and reduce a stock's price history to underlying frequency 
elements (function regression), and as you yourself know (Mattias) NEAT 
can do function regression quite well, but I just don't see this working 
for something as complex and fluid as the stock market. There will 
always be unpredictable external influences and chaotic movements of 
price that cannot be predicted, and for these scenarios a confidence 
output can just say 'dunno', and that to me is a completely accetable 
response.

Colin.
